[SYNTAX]: Complex, winding sentence structures (e.g., "It was Bradley in the Nineties...").
[LEXICON]: Archaic phrasing ("corn-fed American," "exquisite backwater") may disrupt modern readability.
[FLOW]: Frequent long, dense paragraphs without clear breaks.

[STRUCTURE]: Abrupt transition between "Introduction" and "The Boy Printer" chapters with no contextual bridge.
[TRANSITION]: Biographical anecdotes (e.g., picklelime, circus day) lack explicit connection to Bradley’s artistic impact theme.
[LOGIC]: Unresolved shift from discussing Bradley’s legacy to unrelated childhood details.

[SYNTAX]: Complex, lengthy sentences (e.g., "Thoroughly likable...friend!") disrupt smooth flow.
[LEXICON]: Informal fragments (e.g., "You don’t like arithmetic, anyway.") occasionally jar tone.

[TRANSITION]: Abrupt shifts between scenes (e.g., print shop → Chicago studio) lack explicit connectors.
[STRUCTURE]: Subplots (faker/Roosevelt anecdote) feel tangential to main narrative arc.

[LEXICON]: Archaic vocabulary (e.g., "mutton-chops," "shoddy") may slightly impede modern readability.

[STRUCTURE]: Abrupt transitions between disparate scenes (e.g., boss’s home to K&L to freelancing) with minimal connective tissue.

[SYNTAX]: One sentence with overly complex nested structure (cuff reversal anecdote).

[TRANSITION]: Abrupt shifts between descriptive and narrative segments.

[SYNTAX]: Occasionally complex, lengthy sentences may slightly impede immediate clarity.
[LEXICON]: Formal, archaic vocabulary (e.g., "stick-in-hand," "liberal education") but does not obstruct understanding.

[TRANSITION]: Mild abruptness between paragraphs (e.g., shift from historical typography to studio logistics).
[STRUCTURE]: Subtle thematic jumps (e.g., quote insertion, industry trends to personal anecdote) but remains broadly logical.

[SYNTAX]: Occasionally lengthy, complex sentences (e.g., "Caslon types on Strathmore papers having proved so popular...") may impede smooth flow.
[LEXICON]: Specialized printing terminology (e.g., "cylinder press," "deckle edge papers") could reduce accessibility for non-expert readers.

[STRUCTURE]: Abrupt transition from business collapse ("had to go away for a complete rest") to the "INTERLUDE IN NEW YORK" scene without clear narrative bridge.
[TRANSITION]: Sudden shift in tone and setting (e.g., "And now we are in the Gay Nineties...") feels disconnected from preceding paragraphs.

[SYNTAX]: Occasionally complex, lengthy sentences (e.g., "For this I used a special casting...") may slightly impede smooth reading.
[LEXICON]: Archaic phrasing (e.g., "swaddling clothes," "Gibson Girl hangover") could reduce fluency for modern readers.

[TRANSITION]: Abrupt shifts between historical context (e.g., magazine industry evolution) and personal anecdotes (e.g., Collier’s incident).
[STRUCTURE]: Non-sequential mentions of projects (e.g., "Castle Perilous," Collier’s covers) without clear contextual links within the segment.

[SYNTAX]: Occasionally complex, densely packed sentences may slightly impede immediate clarity.

[STRUCTURE]: Minor abruptness in transitioning between tangential creative projects (e.g., "Moongold," literary works).

[SYNTAX]: Occasionally complex sentence structures, though clear and error-free.

[TRANSITION]: Mild abruptness in shifting from professional projects to praising modern illustrators.

[SYNTAX]: Occasionally complex sentence structures (e.g., lengthy explanations of editing processes).
